elements.content: The misuse of organic pollutants such as nitrofuran antibiotics (NFAs) and 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline (DCN) has become a hot topic of global concern, and developing rapid, efficient, and accurate techniques for detecting NFAs and pesticides in water is a major challenge. Here, we designed a novel lead-based anion 2D metal–organic framework (MOF)­{[(CH3)2NH2]2[Pb­(TCBPE)­(H2O)2]} n (F3) with interlocking structures, in which TCBPE stands for 1,1,2,2-tetra­(4-carboxylbiphenyl)­ethylene. Powder X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis revealed that F3 has excellent chemical and solvent stability. It is worth noting that F3 has a grinding discoloration effect. The solvent-protected grinding approach achieved F3B with a high quantum yield (QY = 73.77%) and blue fluorescence, while the direct grinding method produced F3Y with a high quantum yield (QY = 37.27%) and yellow–green fluorescence. Importantly, F3B can detect NFAs in water rapidly and sensitively while remaining unaffected by other antibiotics. F3Y can identify DCN in water quickly and selectively while remaining unchanged by other pesticides. F3B demonstrated high selectivity and rapid response to NFAs at a limit of detection (LOD) as low as 0.26 μM, while F3Y indicated high selectivity and responded quickly to DCN in water at an LOD as low as 0.14 μM. The method was successfully applied to detect NFAs in actual water samples of the fish tanks and ponds as well as the pesticide DCN in soil samples. The recovery rates were 97.0–105.15% and 102.2–106.48%, and the relative standard deviations were 0.63–1.45% and 0.29–1.69%, respectively. In addition, F3B and F3Y can be made into fluorescent test papers for the visual detection of NFAs and DCN, respectively. Combined with experiments and density functional theory calculations, the mechanism of fluorescence quenching of MOFs by target analytes was also revealed.

Here, we designed a novel lead-based anion 2D metal-organic framework (MOF){[(CH3)2NH2]2[Pb(TCBPE)(H2O)2]} n  (F3) with interlocking structures, in which TCBPE stands for 1,1,2,2-tetra(4-carboxylbiphenyl)ethylene. elements.content: With the emerging concern for community health and water quality, detecting trace pollutants (e.g. antibiotics, pesticides, and organic compounds) in wastewater is of great value for ecological civilization construction and sustainable development. Antibiotics are widely used to treat various bacterial infections or diseases caused by pathogenic microorganisms. Even though they have therapeutic value, the abuse of antibiotics is widespread worldwide, and residual antibiotics are eventually ingested by humans through the food chain, causing acute and chronic poisoning. Nitrofuran antibiotics (NFAs) are a class of synthetic broad-spectrum antibiotics widely used in animal husbandry and aquaculture. Recent studies have shown that NFAs have carcinogenic, teratogenic, and other side effects on the human body. On March 22, 2010, the Ministry of Health of China added nitrofurans such as furazolidone, furaltadone, nitrofurantoin, and nitrofurazone to the list of illegal additions of nonedible substances. Unfortunately, various antibiotics have been found in surface water, groundwater, and drinking water. The total use of antibiotics in China in 2013 was approximately 162,000 tons, and this number will increase further with the rapid growth of industry, agriculture, and population. Pesticides are an indispensable part of the development of modern agriculture. Similarly, the abuse of chemical pesticides is also widespread in China, and pesticides will exist in the environment for a long time and cause serious damage to the ecological environment. Therefore, pesticides are also unpopular organic pollutants in wastewater, except for antibiotics. The detection of these specific organic pollutant residues from the environment has aroused widespread concern all over the world but is challenging.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

With the emerging concern for community health and water quality, detecting trace pollutants (e.g. antibiotics, pesticides, and organic compounds) in wastewater is of great value for ecological civilization construction and sustainable development. Antibiotics are widely used to treat various bacterial infections or diseases caused by pathogenic microorganisms. Even though they have therapeutic value, the abuse of antibiotics is widespread worldwide, and residual antibiotics are eventually ingested by humans through the food chain, causing acute and chronic poisoning. Nitrofuran antibiotics (NFAs) are a class of synthetic broad-spectrum antibiotics widely used in animal husbandry and aquaculture. Recent studies have shown that NFAs have carcinogenic, teratogenic, and other side effects on the human body. On March 22, 2010, the Ministry of Health of China added nitrofurans such as furazolidone, furaltadone, nitrofurantoin, and nitrofurazone to the list of illegal additions of nonedible substances. Unfortunately, various antibiotics have been found in surface water, groundwater, and drinking water. The total use of antibiotics in China in 2013 was approximately 162,000 tons, and this number will increase further with the rapid growth of industry, agriculture, and population. Pesticides are an indispensable part of the development of modern agriculture. Similarly, the abuse of chemical pesticides is also widespread in China, and pesticides will exist in the environment for a long time and cause serious damage to the ecological environment. Therefore, pesticides are also unpopular organic pollutants in wastewater, except for antibiotics. The detection of these specific organic pollutant residues from the environment has aroused widespread concern all over the world but is challenging.

elements.content: To date, the detection of antibiotics and pesticides has mainly relied on instrumental methods, such as surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy, liquid and gas chromatography coupled to tandem mass spectrometry (LC/GC–MS), liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC–MS), liquid chromatography with UV-diode array detection, and capillary electrophoresis. Unfortunately, these detection methods are expensive, time-consuming, complex, and poorly portable. Hence, researchers are very concerned about making detection methods and technologies that are easy to use, reliable, and inexpensive so that they can find antibiotic and pesticide residues in nature.

Unfortunately, these detection methods are expensive, time-consuming, complex, and poorly portable. Hence, researchers are very concerned about making detection methods and technologies that are easy to use, reliable, and inexpensive so that they can find antibiotic and pesticide residues in nature.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which are assembled by metal ions or metal clusters and organic ligands through coordination bonds, are considered a good platform for detection and sensing because of their unique electrical and optical properties, permanent porosity, high specific surface area, and ease of modification and design of the structure and function. As a potential fluorescent probe, MOFs have been used to detect metal cations, anions, toxic organic molecules, cancer markers, and biomolecules due to their high selectivity, sensitivity, and recycling.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which are assembled by metal ions or metal clusters and organic ligands through coordination bonds, are considered a good platform for detection and sensing because of their unique electrical and optical properties, permanent porosity, high specific surface area, and ease of modification and design of the structure and function. As a potential fluorescent probe, MOFs have been used to detect metal cations, anions, toxic organic molecules, cancer markers, and biomolecules due to their high selectivity, sensitivity, and recycling.

elements.content: Over the past few decades, many studies have been conducted to detect antibiotics and pesticides. Subhadip Neogi’s group constructed a nonpenetrated framework MOF (CSMCRI-4) by an electron-rich tricarboxylate ligand and realized the detection of 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline (DCN) pesticide and nitrofurazone (NFZ) antibiotic in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution, with limit of detections (LODs) of 0.13 and 0.19 ppm, respectively. Yu’s research group constructed three coordination polymers (CPs) with aromatic polycarboxylic acid ligands. CPs-3 can detect nitrofurantoin (NFT) and NFZ antibiotics, as well as DCN pesticide in DMF solution, and the LODs were 353, 322, and 233 ppb, respectively. In addition, Shi et al. constructed Eu-MOF by using a carboxylate-N-heterocyclic ligands. The Eu-MOF was successfully applied to detect metronidazole (MDZ), dimetridazole (DTZ) antibiotics, and DCN pesticides in water, with LODs of 13, 13.4, and 5.28 ppm, respectively. However, the majority of MOF detection experiments was carried out in organic solvents rather than water, and many luminescent MOFs will breakdown when they come into contact with water, which makes them less useful. Therefore, MOFs with a stable structure and superior luminescence properties in water are more suitable for detecting antibiotics and pesticides. In our previous work, we prepared a series of fluorescent sensors for the detection of quercetin, dinotefuran, nitrophenols, nitrite, and iron ions. Therefore, MOFs are promising materials as fluorescent probes.

elements.content: The rational design of MOFs is very challenging and relies on the rational selection of linkers and metal ions. Carboxylate donor ligands are very important because they have strong coordination abilities in different ways that allow them to meet the geometric needs of metal centers, which leads to higher dimensions and interesting topologies. Pb­(II), as a heavy metal ion in the p-block, has the characteristics of a large radius and multiple coordination numbers, which provides a unique opportunity for constructing a new type of MOF with variable topology and interesting properties. However, to date, most of the studies on MOFs have mainly focused on lanthanide elements and d-block transition metals, while less attention has been given to MOFs based on p-block main group metals. Therefore, the development of innovative Pb-based MOFs and their potential applications is very important.

elements.content: Tetraphenylethene (TPE) and its derivatives are typical organic materials with aggregation-induced emission (AIE) characteristics. The rigid skeleton structure of organometallic compounds introduced with TPE is beneficial for limiting the rotation and vibration of organic groups through hydrogen bonds, π–π stacking, and intermolecular van der Waals forces, thereby reducing the nonradiative transition pathway and increasing emission quantum yield. In addition, high photoluminescence (PL) efficiency can often provide good sensing performance. 1,1,2,2-tetra­(4-carboxylbiphenyl)­ethylene (H4TCBPE), a derivative of TPE, has been employed as a rigid organic ligand to construct luminescent MOFs. To date, some luminescent MOFs based on H4TCBPE have been reported, including Zr6(μ3-O)4(OH)8(tcbpe)2(H2O)4, Zr-MOFs (PCN-94 and PCN-128W), (DMA)­[In (TCBPE)]­(solv), and so on. However, the sensing ability of these TCBPE-MOFs has rarely been explored. Furthermore, the synthesis of Pb-TCBPE and its application in fluorescence sensing for pesticide and antibiotic detection have not been reported.
elements.clean_text: Tetraphenylethene (TPE) and its derivatives are typical organic materials with aggregation-induced emission (AIE) characteristics. The rigid skeleton structure of organometallic compounds introduced with TPE is beneficial for limiting the rotation and vibration of organic groups through hydrogen bonds, π-π stacking, and intermolecular van der Waals forces, thereby reducing the nonradiative transition pathway and increasing emission quantum yield. In addition, high photoluminescence (PL) efficiency can often provide good sensing performance. 1,1,2,2-tetra(4-carboxylbiphenyl)ethylene (H4TCBPE), a derivative of TPE, has been employed as a rigid organic ligand to construct luminescent MOFs. To date, some luminescent MOFs based on H4TCBPE have been reported, including Zr6(μ3-O)4(OH)8(tcbpe)2(H2O)4, Zr-MOFs (PCN-94 and PCN-128W), (DMA)[In (TCBPE)](solv), and so on. However, the sensing ability of these TCBPE-MOFs has rarely been explored. Furthermore, the synthesis of Pb-TCBPE and its application in fluorescence sensing for pesticide and antibiotic detection have not been reported.

elements.content: In this paper, a novel two-dimensional anionic framework­{[(CH3)2NH2]2[Pb (TCBPE) (H2O)2]} n (F3) with superior fluorescence properties was constructed by using the H4TCBPE ligand and lead nitrate. Due to the vertical interlocking structure of F3, it exhibits excellent solvent and fluorescence stability in water and other organic solvents. As a result, it is suitable for fluorescence analysis. The blue luminescent crystal powder (F3B) (PLQY = 73.77%) was obtained by the solvent protection grinding method, and the yellow–green luminescent crystal powder (F3Y) (PLQY = 37.27%) was attained by direct grinding. Based on the fluorescence response characteristics, a dual-color luminescent Pb-TCBPE sensing platform in water was constructed, realizing the detection of NFAs by F3B and the detection of DCN by F3Y. The linear range of NFAs was 0.86–29.91 μM with a detection limit of 0.26 μM, whereas the linear range of DCN was 0.46–59.64 μM with a detection limit of 0.14 μM. The method was successfully applied to detect NFAs in actual water samples of fish tanks and ponds and the pesticide DCN in soil samples. The recovery rates were 97.0–105.15% and 102.2–106.48%, and the relative standard deviations (RSDs) were 0.63–1.45% and 0.29–1.69%, respectively. Finally, we prepared a portable fluorescent test paper to visualize and rapidly detect NFAs and pesticide DCN. In addition, the quenching mechanism was investigated by experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Notably, this work is the first to propose a variety of solvent-protected strategies for the preparation of TCBPE-MOFs. This is also the first time that Pb-TCBPE has been synthesized and used to detect antibiotics and pesticides in water, which contributes to the development of multifunctional fluorescent MOF sensors.

elements.content: Lead­(II) nitrate [Pb­(NO3)2] was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. H4TCBPE was purchased from Jilin Chinese Academy of Sciences-Yanshen Technology Co., Ltd. Sulfabenzamide (SBZ), sulfathiazole (STZ), sulfadimethoxine (SDX), sulfamethoxazole (SMZ), MDZ, DTZ, tinidazole (TDZ), ornidazole (ODZ), florfenicol (FFN), thiamphenicol (THI), hexachlorobenzene (HCB), amoxicillin (ACL), and erythromycin (ERM) were purchased from Beijing J & K Scientific Ltd. Carboxin (CBX), cyfluthrin (CFT), metalaxyl (MTL), cymoxanil (CML), DCN, fipronil (FPL), carbendazim (CBD), NFT, NFZ, and methylparaben (MPB) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. DMF and acetonitrile (ACN) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. All chemical reagents were at least of analytical grade and were directly used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

Reagents and Chemicals

Lead(II) nitrate [Pb(NO3)2] was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. H4TCBPE was purchased from Jilin Chinese Academy of Sciences-Yanshen Technology Co., Ltd. Sulfabenzamide (SBZ), sulfathiazole (STZ), sulfadimethoxine (SDX), sulfamethoxazole (SMZ), MDZ, DTZ, tinidazole (TDZ), ornidazole (ODZ), florfenicol (FFN), thiamphenicol (THI), hexachlorobenzene (HCB), amoxicillin (ACL), and erythromycin (ERM) were purchased from Beijing J & K Scientific Ltd. Carboxin (CBX), cyfluthrin (CFT), metalaxyl (MTL), cymoxanil (CML), DCN, fipronil (FPL), carbendazim (CBD), NFT, NFZ, and methylparaben (MPB) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. DMF and acetonitrile (ACN) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. All chemical reagents were at least of analytical grade and were directly used without further purification.

elements.content: The UV–vis absorption spectra were measured using a UV-2700 UV spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with an STA 449 F3 analyzer (NETZSCH, Germany) heated from 30 °C at a rate of 20 °C·min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was obtained on a DX-2700 diffractometer (Dandong Haoyuan Instrument Co., Ltd, China) with Cu Kα radiation. Fourier transform spectra (FT-IR) were collected using a WQF-510A spectrometer (Beijing Beifen Ruili Analytical Instrument Co., Ltd, China). The luminescent spectra were obtained on a Fluorolog-3 fluorescence spectrometer (HORIBA, USA), and solid reagents were weighed using an XSE 205DU (METTLER TOLEDO, Switzerland). Elemental analysis (C, H, and N) was performed on an Elementar Vario EL Cube (German Element, Germany). Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was carried out by a Nanoscope V Multimode 8 scanning probe microscope from Bruker Corporation.
elements.clean_text:
Apparatus and Characterization

The UV-vis absorption spectra were measured using a UV-2700 UV spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with an STA 449 F3 analyzer (NETZSCH, Germany) heated from 30 °C at a rate of 20 °C⋅min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was obtained on a DX-2700 diffractometer (Dandong Haoyuan Instrument Co., Ltd, China) with Cu Kα radiation. Fourier transform spectra (FT-IR) were collected using a WQF-510A spectrometer (Beijing Beifen Ruili Analytical Instrument Co., Ltd, China). The luminescent spectra were obtained on a Fluorolog-3 fluorescence spectrometer (HORIBA, USA), and solid reagents were weighed using an XSE 205DU (METTLER TOLEDO, Switzerland). Elemental analysis (C, H, and N) was performed on an Elementar Vario EL Cube (German Element, Germany). Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was carried out by a Nanoscope V Multimode 8 scanning probe microscope from Bruker Corporation.

elements.content: H4TCBPE (8 mg, 0.009 mM) and Pb­(NO3)2 (5.96 mg, 0.018 mM) were mixed with DMF (1.5 mL), ACN (0.5 mL), and water (0.5 mL), and 100 μL of 6 M HCl was added to adjust the pH value. The mixture was sonicated for 30 min and then sealed into a 10 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 120 °C for three days and cooled slowly to 25 °C. Pale yellow square crystals were collected and washed with DMF, ACN, and water and then dried naturally. The yield was approximately 44.88% [based on Pb­(NO3)2]. Synthesis of {[(CH3)2NH2]2[Pb(TCBPE)(H2O)2]} n  (F3)

H4TCBPE (8 mg, 0.009 mM) and Pb(NO3)2 (5.96 mg, 0.018 mM) were mixed with DMF (1.5 mL), ACN (0.5 mL), and water (0.5 mL), and 100 μL of 6 M HCl was added to adjust the pH value. The mixture was sonicated for 30 min and then sealed into a 10 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 120 °C for three days and cooled slowly to 25 °C. Pale yellow square crystals were collected and washed with DMF, ACN, and water and then dried naturally. The yield was approximately 44.88% [based on Pb(NO3)2]. elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Experiment Details

0.5 mg of F3B powder obtained by solvent protection grinding was dispersed into ultrapure water (50 mL), and the concentration of 0.01 mg/mL suspension was prepared by ultrasonication for 20 min. Then, 2 mL of suspension was transferred into a quartz cuvette, and the fluorescence spectra were recorded at an excitation wavelength of 365 nm.

elements.content: The concentration of 10 mM antibiotic NFZ or NFT solution was added to the suspension in the fluorescence titration experiment, and the fluorescence spectra were recorded under the same conditions. In the selective experiment, 14 kinds of antibiotic (SBZ, STZ, SDX, SMZ, MDZ, DTZ, TDZ, ODZ, FFN, THI, ACL, ERM, NFZ, and NFT) solutions (40 μL, 10 mM) were added to the suspension, and the fluorescence spectra were recorded.

In the selective experiment, 14 kinds of antibiotic (SBZ, STZ, SDX, SMZ, MDZ, DTZ, TDZ, ODZ, FFN, THI, ACL, ERM, NFZ, and NFT) solutions (40 μL, 10 mM) were added to the suspension, and the fluorescence spectra were recorded.

elements.content: In the anti-interference experiment, it is important to explore whether the other 12 kinds of antibiotics will interfere with the detection of NFAs by F3B. The fluorescence spectra were recorded after adding the above 12 kinds of antibiotics (40 μL, 10 mM) to the suspension, and then, the changes in fluorescence spectra were recorded after adding the solution of NFAs (40 μL, 10 mM).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data were obtained from a Bruker D8 Venture single crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The structure of F3 was solved by direct methods and refined to convergence by the least squares method on F 2 using the SHELXL (Olex 2) software suite. In addition, all atoms except the hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. We used the PLATON/SQUEEZE program to remove disordered molecules. Finally, the molecular formula of compound F3 was determined by TGA. Detailed crystal data and structure refinements for F3 are listed in Tables S1 and S2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination

Single-crystal X-ray data were obtained from a Bruker D8 Venture single crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The structure of F3 was solved by direct methods and refined to convergence by the least squares method on F 2 using the SHELXL (Olex 2) software suite. In addition, all atoms except the hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. We used the PLATON/SQUEEZE program to remove disordered molecules. Finally, the molecular formula of compound F3 was determined by TGA. Detailed crystal data and structure refinements for F3 are listed in Tables S1 and S2.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that F3 crystallizes in the tetragonal system with space group P4/m (Table S1). Each asymmetric unit contains a Pb­(II) ion, a deprotonated TCBPE4– anion ligand, and two coordinated water molecules. The [(CH3)2NH2]+ generated from the in situ decomposition of DMF is used as a counterion to balance the charge. As shown in a, the Pb­(II) ion is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms (O1, O11, O12, O13; 1: 1 – X,Y,1 – Z; 2: +X,+Y,1 – Z; and 3: 1 – X,Y,+Z) from four different TCBPE4– ligands and two oxygen atoms (O2,O21) from two coordinated water molecules, which generate the octahedron coordination geometry as calculated by SHAPE 2.0 software (Table S3). The Pb–O bond length ranged from 2.63 to 2.68 Å, which matched well with previous research. The TCBPE4– ligand in F3 adopts a μ4–η1η1η1η1 linking pattern coordinated with four Pb­(II) ions, and the deprotonated carboxyl group can provide an active site that can be used for detection. Pb­(II) and TCBPE4– are connected by coordination, extending the Pb-TCBPE backbone into a two-dimensional network structure along the bc plane (b). Since the formed two-dimensional matrix lattice has a large cavity, the large aperture allows the same network to interpenetrate regularly, forming a two-dimensional interlocking structure with twofold vertical interpolation (Figure S1a,b). The presence of square apertures of approximately 6.75 × 6.75 Å2 along the ab plane further strengthens the stability of the entire skeleton (c). The framework can be simplified to a 4,4-connected structure (d). According to the PLATON program, the total potential volume of the framework is estimated to be 7.5%.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Description

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that F3 crystallizes in the tetragonal system with space group P4/m (Table S1). Each asymmetric unit contains a Pb(II) ion, a deprotonated TCBPE4- anion ligand, and two coordinated water molecules. The [(CH3)2NH2]+ generated from the in situ decomposition of DMF is used as a counterion to balance the charge. As shown in a, the Pb(II) ion is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms (O1, O11, O12, O13; 1: 1 - X,Y,1 - Z; 2: +X,+Y,1 - Z; and 3: 1 - X,Y,+Z) from four different TCBPE4- ligands and two oxygen atoms (O2,O21) from two coordinated water molecules, which generate the octahedron coordination geometry as calculated by SHAPE 2.0 software (Table S3). The Pb-O bond length ranged from 2.63 to 2.68 Å, which matched well with previous research. The TCBPE4- ligand in F3 adopts a μ4-η1η1η1η1 linking pattern coordinated with four Pb(II) ions, and the deprotonated carboxyl group can provide an active site that can be used for detection. Pb(II) and TCBPE4- are connected by coordination, extending the Pb-TCBPE backbone into a two-dimensional network structure along the bc plane (b). Since the formed two-dimensional matrix lattice has a large cavity, the large aperture allows the same network to interpenetrate regularly, forming a two-dimensional interlocking structure with twofold vertical interpolation (Figure S1a,b). The presence of square apertures of approximately 6.75 × 6.75 Å2 along the ab plane further strengthens the stability of the entire skeleton (c). The framework can be simplified to a 4,4-connected structure (d). According to the PLATON program, the total potential volume of the framework is estimated to be 7.5%.

elements.content: MOFs for fluorescence sensing analysis are often used in the liquid phase because the material and the target can be mixed uniformly in the liquid phase to speed up the reaction. The purpose of qualitative and quantitative detection is achieved through fluorescence enhancement, quenching, or peak shift. Pretreatment for fluorescent MOF sensors usually involves grinding the block into powder in a mortar, then dispersing it into an aqueous phase or an organic phase, and then ultrasonically dispersing the suspension before performing fluorescence analysis. However, we found that F3 exhibited grinding discoloration effect in the course of the experiment, which is similar to the previous report. Under the daylight lamp, the crystal color changed from light yellow to yellow by direct grinding, and the corresponding fluorescent color changed from blue to yellow–green under UV light irradiation (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text:
Optimization of the Grinding Method

MOFs for fluorescence sensing analysis are often used in the liquid phase because the material and the target can be mixed uniformly in the liquid phase to speed up the reaction. The purpose of qualitative and quantitative detection is achieved through fluorescence enhancement, quenching, or peak shift. Pretreatment for fluorescent MOF sensors usually involves grinding the block into powder in a mortar, then dispersing it into an aqueous phase or an organic phase, and then ultrasonically dispersing the suspension before performing fluorescence analysis. However, we found that F3 exhibited grinding discoloration effect in the course of the experiment, which is similar to the previous report. Under the daylight lamp, the crystal color changed from light yellow to yellow by direct grinding, and the corresponding fluorescent color changed from blue to yellow-green under UV light irradiation (Figure S2).

elements.content: From a literature review, we identified DMF protection as the only method for grinding TCBPE-MOFs to obtain crystal powder that emits blue fluorescence in water. That is, adding DMF as a protective agent in the grinding process can effectively prevent the configuration change of bulk crystals in the process of grinding into powder, thus maintaining blue fluorescence. Given this, we removed the crystals in the reactor, washed them with DMF and water three times, and then vacuum-dried them at 65 °C overnight. Considering the subsequent experiments for sensing applications in the liquid phase, we improved the method reported in the above literature and processed it in the following two ways. The first treatment method was to weigh 2 mg of the abovementioned bulk crystal F3 into 5 mortars and add 200 μL of different solvents, including H2O, ethanol, DMF, acetone, and methanol. After fully grinding, they were appropriately diluted with the corresponding solvent, and the fluorescence spectra of the obtained solutions are shown in Figure S3. The second method was to weigh 2 mg of the abovementioned bulk crystal F3 in a mortar, add 200 μL of DMF as a protective agent, grind it sufficiently, add an appropriate amount of DMF, and transfer it to a centrifuge tube. The resulting precipitate after centrifugation was washed three times with acetonitrile and then dried under vacuum at 65 °C. The obtained products were prepared with H2O, ethanol, DMF, acetone, and methanol as solvents to obtain five kinds of suspensions with a concentration of 0.01 mg/mL. The fluorescence spectra are shown in Figure S4.

elements.content: From the above experiments, we found that the luminescent positions of the suspended crystals obtained by the two treatment methods are the same. The above results prove that the solvent protection method is not limited to DMF and that methanol, ethanol, and acetone can protect TCBPE crystals from damage during the grinding process. More importantly, as a nontoxic and harmless solvent, water can also play a protective role. This is the first time that various solvents have been explored and confirmed as grinding protection. To accurately quantify, water was used as a protection to obtain F3B, which was dried after centrifugation and then dispersed into ultra-pure water to obtain an F3B suspension with blue fluorescence. Here, F3B specifically refers to the blue-emitting fluorescent crystal obtained by the water-protected grinding process, and F3Y refers to the yellow green-emitting fluorescent crystal obtained by the direct grinding method.

elements.content: To explain why adding solvents can protect crystals, we chose the nonpolar solvents benzene or toluene for the grinding process. As shown in Figure S5a,b, adding benzene or toluene can still play a protective role. Considering the small steric hindrance of these organic solvents, we speculate that they can easily enter the crystal channel to protect the crystal framework, thus playing a role in protecting the crystal structure. To prove the above hypothesis, we chose undecylenic acid and oleic acid with large steric hindrance. Figure S5c,d shows that after grinding with undecylenic acid and oleic acid, the fluorescence peaks are located at 480 and 490 nm, respectively, and the peak position is redshifted to 19 and 29 nm compared with F3B. In addition, the shape of the fluorescence obtained by undecylenic acid and oleic acid grinding is the same as that obtained by direct grinding because adding undecylenic acid and oleic acid cannot completely play a protective role due to the large steric hindrance. Since undecylenic acid and oleic acids have high steric hindrance and cannot enter the crystal pore channels, a phenomenon similar to direct grinding occurs during the grinding process. Hence, we suppose that the entry of solvent molecules with low steric hindrance into the pores plays a protective role. In addition, through scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis (Figure S6), uniformly dispersed and small crystal particles can be obtained either by adding solvents or by a direct grinding process. The roughness of the crystals was characterized by AFM. Figure S7 shows that the surface roughness of F3 grinding with water, DMF, oleic acid, and direct grinding was 0.00343, 0.00102, 0.00782, and 0.0113 μm, respectively. Because the solvent molecules are in direct contact with the crystal, which plays the role of “lubrication” in the grinding process, the quality of the crystal is protected in the grinding process into small particles. In brief, solvent protection is mainly in the pores and surface. Through the solvent protection strategy, the bulk crystal can be well ground into powder without destroying its structure. shows the fluorescence images of F3 grinding with H2O, acetone, DMF, ethyl alcohol, benzene, methyl benzene, methyl alcohol, undecylenic acid, oleic acid, and directly.

elements.content: To study the reason for the grinding discoloration of F3, first, the crystal structure was analyzed. a shows that F3 has an interspersed vertical structure, and the two adjacent faces formed a stable structure through the molecule C–H···π interaction (H19 to centroid distance = 2.836 Å and H18 to centroid distance = 3.287 Å, b). The grinding process may destroy the stable structure and cause a change in fluorescence location. Molecular level changes of F3 discoloration in the grinding process are analyzed by infrared spectroscopy (c). The out-of-plane aromatic C–H frequencies in F3 are blueshifted from 860.1 and 836.9 cm–1 to 858.1 and 835.0 cm–1 in F3Y, indicating the change in symmetry and the weakening of intermolecular interactions, such as C–H···π. In addition, the redshift of the stretching vibration of COO– in F3 from 1681.6 to 1687.4 cm–1 in F3Y indicates that certain changes have occurred in the functional group (d). Infrared analysis shows that the degree of intermolecular interaction is greatly disturbed during grinding, and the weakening of intermolecular interaction in the solid state will lead to the loss of crystallinity and long-range order, which will also be reflected in the PXRD patterns of F3Y. Furthermore, we collected the PXRD pattern of F3Y. As shown in e, F3 has two sharp and strong diffraction peaks at 2θ = 12.26 and 19.1° and several diffraction peaks at 2θ = 7.82–36.68°, showing better crystallinity. Some peaks in F3Y became weaker, indicating that the main crystal structure was destroyed by mechanical force, showing a transition trend to a quasi-amorphous state. The weakening or disappearance of some diffraction peaks indicates that the interpenetrating long-range ordered structure was destroyed. In contrast, the significantly increased diffraction peaks (2θ = 19.18, 19.92, and 24.82°) indicate that the ordered part of a certain position is enhanced during grinding. The increase in intermolecular π–π interaction distance caused by a change in diffraction angles has a significant impact on fluorescence emission. After grinding the ligands (f), we found that the ligands also have the phenomenon of grinding discoloration because the grinding process can cause intermolecular sliding and change the position of the fluorescence peak.

elements.content: Under the optical microscope, F3 was shown as a regularly shaped pale-yellow square (Figure S8a). The surface of F3 was observed by SEM (Figure S8b), suggesting that F3 was smooth and free of impurities, and the surface roughness (Rq) of F3 measured by AFM was only 0.00146 μm (Figure S8c). The above results show that F3 has a good morphology and smooth surface. PXRD was carried out to confirm the phase purity of compound F3. The positions of the prominent diffraction peaks of the PXRD patterns measured in the experiment are consistent with the simulated ones, proving that F3 is a pure phase (Figure S9). Then, after soaking in aqueous solutions with different pH values for 12 h, the prominent diffraction peaks of the PXRD patterns are still consistent with the simulated peaks, indicating that F3 can remain stable in the pH range of 2–12 (Figure S10a). As depicted in Figure S10b, F3 maintained excellent crystallinity, and the PXRD patterns are in agreement with the simulated patterns after soaking in water and different organic solvents for 12 h, indicating that compound F3 has superb solvent stability. The stability of the solvent lays the foundation for fluorescence sensing in the liquid phase.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Characterization of Compound F3 

Under the optical microscope, F3 was shown as a regularly shaped pale-yellow square (Figure S8a). The surface of F3 was observed by SEM (Figure S8b), suggesting that F3 was smooth and free of impurities, and the surface roughness (Rq) of F3 measured by AFM was only 0.00146 μm (Figure S8c). The above results show that F3 has a good morphology and smooth surface. PXRD was carried out to confirm the phase purity of compound F3. The positions of the prominent diffraction peaks of the PXRD patterns measured in the experiment are consistent with the simulated ones, proving that F3 is a pure phase (Figure S9). Then, after soaking in aqueous solutions with different pH values for 12 h, the prominent diffraction peaks of the PXRD patterns are still consistent with the simulated peaks, indicating that F3 can remain stable in the pH range of 2-12 (Figure S10a). As depicted in Figure S10b, F3 maintained excellent crystallinity, and the PXRD patterns are in agreement with the simulated patterns after soaking in water and different organic solvents for 12 h, indicating that compound F3 has superb solvent stability. The stability of the solvent lays the foundation for fluorescence sensing in the liquid phase.

elements.content: XPS spectra were used to determine the elemental composition and valence state of F3. As seen from Figure S11a, elements in complex F3 include Pb, C, N, and O. The high-resolution spectrum of Pb 4f shows that the binding energies are 138.88 eV (Pb 4f7/2) and 143.78 eV (Pb 4f5/2), which prove the existence of Pb­(II) ions (Figure S11b). Figure S11c shows that the high-resolution XPS spectrum of C 1s is convolved into two peaks, with binding energies of 284.80 and 288.27 eV corresponding to the C–C bond and the O–CO bond, respectively, which correspond to carboxylic acid ligands. Figure S11d shows the N 1s high-resolution XPS spectrum with one convolution peak at 402.82 eV attributable to C–NH2, further proving the existence of the dimethylamine cation. Figure S11e shows O 1s high-resolution XPS with two convolution peaks at 531.67 and 533.44 eV attributable to the Pb–O bond and the CO bond.

elements.content: The relationship between the ligand H4TCBPE and compound F3 was investigated using infrared spectroscopy (Figure S12). For H4TCBPE, the characteristic peak of 1681.6 cm–1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of CO. For F3B and F3Y, the absorption peak at 3421 cm–1 is the O–H bond absorption peak originating from the coordinated water molecule. For F3B, the absorption peak at 1394.3 cm–1 is attributed to the strong stretching vibration of COO–, while the absorption peak intensity at 1681.6 cm–1 is significantly decreased, suggesting that the coordination between Pb2+ and the carboxyl group shows the formation of the crystal framework. For F3Y, the characteristic peak of the carbonyl group shifts to 1687.4 cm–1, indicating that configuration changes may occur.

elements.content: TGA data were collected in the range of 30 to 800 °C at a rate of 20 °C min–1 under a nitrogen atmosphere to investigate F3’s thermal stability. As shown in Figure S13, the weight loss rate of the TGA curve is approximately 3.12% (calculated to be 3.15%) from 30–138 °C, proving the loss of two coordinated water molecules in F3. When the temperature was increased to 430 °C, the mass of F3 decreased sharply, which was attributed to the collapse of the framework. The above result showed that F3 has excellent thermal stability.

elements.content: The diffuse reflectance spectra of F3B, F3Y, and H4TCBPE were measured to investigate the solid-state absorption properties (Figure S14a). The diffuse reflectance spectra showed that H4TCBPE has a wider absorption band range from 290 to 600 nm, while F3B and F3Y exhibited an apparent sharp absorption range from 290 to 500 nm, which is obviously blueshifted compared to H4TCBPE absorption. Therefore, F3B, F3Y, and H4TCBPE exhibit different colors: H4TCBPE has a bright yellow color due to the absorption of blue light, whereas F3B has a pale yellow color due to less absorption in the visible region. F3Y has a yellow color similar to H4TCBPE due to partial absorption of blue in the visible region (Figure S14b–d). The wide absorption band of 290–500 nm is attributed to the π → π* and n → π* transitions, consistent with the H4TCBPE ligand. Therefore, the absorption bands of F3B and F3Y mainly come from the H4TCBPE ligand.

Photophysical Properties

The diffuse reflectance spectra of F3B, F3Y, and H4TCBPE were measured to investigate the solid-state absorption properties (Figure S14a). The diffuse reflectance spectra showed that H4TCBPE has a wider absorption band range from 290 to 600 nm, while F3B and F3Y exhibited an apparent sharp absorption range from 290 to 500 nm, which is obviously blueshifted compared to H4TCBPE absorption. Therefore, F3B, F3Y, and H4TCBPE exhibit different colors: H4TCBPE has a bright yellow color due to the absorption of blue light, whereas F3B has a pale yellow color due to less absorption in the visible region. F3Y has a yellow color similar to H4TCBPE due to partial absorption of blue in the visible region (Figure S14b-d). The wide absorption band of 290-500 nm is attributed to the π → π* and n → π* transitions, consistent with the H4TCBPE ligand. Therefore, the absorption bands of F3B and F3Y mainly come from the H4TCBPE ligand.

elements.content: CPs of main-group metals such as Pb­(II) have interesting photochemical and photophysical properties, but there have been few studies on their PL compared with transition metals and lanthanide metals. a shows that F3B and F3Y have broad excitation spectra ranging from 300 to 400 nm. As a practical application, the UV lamp can be used for visual detection, so we all use 365 nm as the wavelength for excitation. As shown in b, the maximum emission wavelengths of F3B, F3Y, and the ligand H4TCBPE are 461, 507, and 484 nm, respectively. The luminescence of F3B and F3Y can be attributed to the charge transfer from ligand-to-metal (LMCT) between the delocalized π-bond of the carboxylic group and the p-orbital of the Pb­(II) center. As shown in c, the fluorescence lifetime of F3Y is 2.08 ns, the fluorescence lifetime of F3B is 1.05 ns, and the fluorescence lifetime of the ligand H4TCBPE is 1.89 ns. Interestingly, the order of life span is in line with the trend of luminous centers, which is consistent with a previous report. The Commission International de I’Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity coordinates of H4TCBPE, F3B, and F3Y are (0.1914, 0.3339), (0.1563, 0.1818), and (0.2672, 0.4273), respectively (d). In addition, both crystal suspensions maintained good dispersibility in water under daylight lamps (e). Moreover, under irradiation with UV light, both crystal suspensions exhibited dazzling fluorescence (f). The quantum yield of F3B in water is as high as 73.77%, and the quantum yield of F3Y powder in water is as high as 37.27%.

elements.content: The high PL efficiency of MOF materials can often provide good sensing properties, especially for detecting electron-deficient molecules. Fluorescent MOFs are usually good electron donors because of a certain degree of conjugation in their organic junctions. The ability of MOFs as donors can be effectively enhanced after excitation, and the electrostatic interaction between MOFs and electron-deficient molecules is further enhanced by exciton migration. However, most MOFs have poor water stability, and many luminescent MOFs will collapse upon exposure to water, limiting their practical application. In addition, most MOF detection was carried out in organic solvents rather than in water. Therefore, detection in an aqueous medium is highly desirable.
elements.clean_text:
Sensing Properties of F3 

The high PL efficiency of MOF materials can often provide good sensing properties, especially for detecting electron-deficient molecules. Fluorescent MOFs are usually good electron donors because of a certain degree of conjugation in their organic junctions. The ability of MOFs as donors can be effectively enhanced after excitation, and the electrostatic interaction between MOFs and electron-deficient molecules is further enhanced by exciton migration. However, most MOFs have poor water stability, and many luminescent MOFs will collapse upon exposure to water, limiting their practical application. In addition, most MOF detection was carried out in organic solvents rather than in water. Therefore, detection in an aqueous medium is highly desirable.

elements.content: To prove the application value of F3B in realistic environments, the fluorescence response characteristics of F3B under different pH values were investigated. Figure S15a shows that the fluorescence intensity of F3B did not change much in the pH range from 2 to 12, indicating that the probe could maintain fluorescence stability over a wide pH range. In addition, the effect of different kinds of ions on the fluorescence intensity of F3B was also investigated. As shown in Figure S15b, the effect of these cations and anions on the luminescence intensity is negligible. F3B was immersed in 10 kinds of common organic solvents (Figure S15c) and a pH range from 2 to 12 for 12 h, and PXRD patterns were collected (Figure S15d). The PXRD pattern showed that F3B maintained good crystallinity after soaking. This means that F3B is stable in different solvents and over a wide range of pH values. To explore the sensing ability of F3B to trace antibiotics in aqueous solutions, the stability of F3B in water was analyzed by time-dependent luminescence intensity. As shown in Figure S16, F3B exhibited a characteristic emission peak at 461 nm, which is close to the emission peak of the ligand (485 nm), indicating that the luminescence of F3B is mainly attributed to the emission of the organic ligand. After 5 h of immersion in water, the fluorescence intensity of F3B did not change. Moreover, the fluorescence intensity decreased only slightly after extending the time to 24 h.

elements.content: The results showed that F3B has good water stability and satisfied the requirements for testing in water. Considering that F3B has good stability and excellent fluorescence performance in water, we explored whether F3B can detect NFAs from five classes of frequently used antibiotics, including sulfonamides (SBZ, STZ, SDX, and SMZ), nitroimidazoles (MDZ, DTZ, TDZ, and ODZ), chloramphenicols (FFN and THI), β-lactams (ACL and ERM), and nitrofurans (NFT and NFZ), where the concentrations were all 10 mM. Figure S17 shows the molecular structure of antibiotics. In a typical experiment, an F3B suspension with a concentration of 0.01 mg/mL was prepared in ultrapure water, 40 μL of antibiotic was added to 2 mL of crystal suspension, and the fluorescence spectra were collected by fluorescence spectrophotometry. In a, compared with other antibiotics, the nitroimidazoles (DTZ, MDZ, ODZ, and TDZ) caused a slight quenching of F3B. However, after adding the same amount of NFT or NFZ, the quenching of F3B was complete, indicating that F3B has high selectivity for NFT or NFZ in the presence of other antibiotics in water.

elements.content: To further demonstrate that NFT or NFZ induces fluorescence quenching, we performed a concentration-dependent study of the luminescence properties of F3B in the presence of NFZ or NFT. It can be observed that with the addition of NFZ or NFT, the fluorescence intensity of F3B gradually decreases (Figures S18a and S19a). Furthermore, when the NFZ or NFT concentration was increased to 196.078 μM, the fluorescence intensity was almost completely quenched, and the quenching efficiency of NFZ and NFT was 92.6 and 90.4%, respectively (Figures S18b and S19b). The quenching effect can be quantitatively calculated by the Stern–Volmer expression: I 0/I – 1 = K sv [C] (I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of F3B before and after adding the analyte, respectively); [C] = the analyte concentration; K sv is the quenching constant (M–1). As shown in Figures S18c and S19c, the fluorescence intensity of the I 0/I ratio has a good linear relationship with the NFZ or NFT concentration in the range of 1.15–29.91 μM and 1.09–29.91 μM, respectively. The K sv value is calculated as 1.934 × 104 for NFZ and 2.01 × 104 for NFT, revealing a strong quenching effect on the luminescence emission intensity of F3B. Based on 3σ/k (the RSD of 10 blank measurements is expressed as σ; and k represents the slope of linear fitting between the concentration and the relative luminescence intensity in the linear range), the LODs for NFZ and NFT are estimated to be 0.35 and 0.33 μM, respectively. Moreover, the optical images of F3B in water before and after the addition of 196.078 μM NFZ or NFT had obvious luminescence color changes (Figures S18d and S19d), indicating that F3B has the potential to be a portable sensor based on the naked eye. The fluorescence titration experiments showed that F3B has good application prospects in the detection of NFZ or NFT in water.

elements.content: The ability of NFZ and NFT to quench F3B was comparable, so the total amount of NFAs (NFZ + NFT) in the mixed solution could be determined. Then, equal volumes of NFZ and NFT mixed at the same concentration were explored by the quenching efficiency of F3B. When adding the same concentration of NFAs (196.078 μM), the ability to quench F3B is equivalent to that of adding NFZ or NFT alone, which means that NFAs have no synergistic or antagonistic effect on quenching F3B, so F3B can detect the total amount of NFAs (b). Furthermore, the fluorescence intensity of F3B decreased rapidly (within 1 min), when 40 μL of NFAs solution was added, and the decreased fluorescence intensity remained unchanged within 60 min (Figure S20). The above results indicate that F3B can be used as a fluorescent probe to detect NFAs rapidly in water.

elements.content: In addition, the ability of F3B as a fluorescence probe to detect NFAs was explored by a fluorescence titration experiment. The fluorescence intensity of F3B decreased gradually with increasing concentrations (0–196.078 μM) of NFAs (a). As shown in b,c, in the range of low concentrations (0.86–29.91 μM), the relationship between the concentration of NFAs and the fluorescence intensity of F3B agrees with the S–V equation, showing a good linear relationship. With a further increase in the concentration, the S–V plot deviated from linearity and bent upward, and the linear relationship agrees with the first-order exponential fitting equation, which may be attributed to the existence of static or dynamic quenching processes or energy transfer processes. When the concentration of NFAs reached 196.078 μM, the fluorescence intensity quenching of F3B was visible to the naked eye (d), and the quenching rate was 93.66%. The K sv value of NFAs was 20340 M–1, and the LOD was calculated to be 0.26 μM.

elements.content: It is essential to explore whether the detection sensitivity of F3B on NFAs will be affected by the other 12 kinds of antibiotics. Hence, we explored the fluorescence response of F3B toward other potentially interfering antibiotics. The concentration of interfering antibiotics and NFAs was 196.078 μM, and the fluorescence response was recorded before and after the addition of interfering antibiotics and NFAs. As shown in Figure S21a, after adding interfering antibiotics, a slight or negligible fluorescence change was observed, and the fluorescence intensity of F3B was significantly quenched when NFAs were added to F3B and mixed with other antibiotics. Hence, it is proven that F3B has high selectivity and anti-interference ability for the detection of NFAs.

elements.content: Recyclability is an important condition for whether MOFs can be used as fluorescent probes in practical applications. The structural stability of MOFs provides a necessary condition for recycling, so we carried out a fluorescence cycle experiment on F3B. At the end of the fluorescence sensing experiment, the suspension of F3B was collected by centrifugation and then washed with DMF, ethanol, and water three times, and then, a new cycle could be carried out. As shown in Figure S21b, F3B can return to its original luminous level and can still be quenched after adding NFAs. In addition, the detection performance of F3B for NFAs did not decrease after five cycles. Meanwhile, after five cycles, the PXRD patterns were in good agreement with the simulation patterns, indicating that the F3B framework remained stable during the cycling procedure (Figure S22). The low detection limit, strong anti-interference ability, and renewable ability showed that F3B can be used as an excellent selective and sensitive fluorescence probe for the detection of NFAs in water.

elements.content: We accidently discovered that F3Y could detect the pesticide of DCN, so we investigated the quenching process of F3Y by DCN. Figure S23a shows that F3Y has good fluorescence stability in the pH range of 5–9. The addition of common ions to the environment has almost no effect on the fluorescence intensity of F3Y (Figure S23b). After immersing F3Y in 10 kinds of common organic solvents and a pH aqueous solution (pH range from 2 to 12) for 12 h, the PXRD patterns were collected. The results showed that the shape of the diffraction peak and position of F3Y were unchanged in the pH range of 5–9 and water (Figure S23d). In the pH range of 2–4, 10–12 and organic solvents (Figure S23c,e,f), F3Y appeared at a new diffraction peak, resulting from the interaction between the crystal and organic solvent, strong acid, and alkali solution. In this work, F3Y is applied in water, so we consider that F3Y has good stability in water and a pH range of 5–9. The fluorescence stability of F3Y in water was analyzed by time-dependent luminescence intensity. F3Y exhibited a characteristic emission peak at 507 nm. In addition, the position and intensity of the fluorescence peak of F3Y in water for 5 h were unchanged, while the fluorescence intensity decreased after extending the time for 24 h. However, the position of the fluorescence peak remained unchanged (Figure S24). The above results showed that F3Y has good fluorescence stability in water.

elements.content: Then, 1 mg of F3Y crystal powder was dispersed in 40 mL of water, and the final concentration of the suspension was 0.025 mg/mL. To evaluate the selectivity of F3Y, we selected nine common pesticides, including CML, MPB, HCB, CFT, CBX, MTL, CBD, FPL, and DCN. Figure S25 shows the molecular structure of pesticides, and their concentrations were all 10 mM. The fluorescence spectra of 32 μL of the above pesticides were collected after they were added to 2 mL of F3Y suspension. The quenching effect was noticeable only when DCN was added, but the quenching effect was negligible when other pesticides of the same concentration were added (). The above results showed that F3Y can selectively recognize DCN. The fluorescence intensity of F3Y was rapidly quenched and remained unchanged within 1 h after adding 32 μL of DCN, which indicated that F3Y could be used as a fluorescent probe to detect DCN rapidly in water (Figure S26).

elements.content: In addition, the sensitivity of the probe was studied by dripping DCN solution into an F3Y suspension, and the changes in the fluorescence spectra were recorded (a). The fluorescence intensity of F3Y decreased with increasing DCN concentration, and the fluorescence quenching rate reached 79.59% when the concentration reached 176.82 μM. In the low concentration range of 0.46–59.64 μM, the concentration of DCN and the fluorescence intensity of F3Y complied with the Stern–Volmer equation, showing a good linear relationship (R 2 = 0.999). With increasing DCN concentration, the S–V equation gradually shifts and bends downward, which may be attributed to the static or dynamic quenching relationship or energy transfer processes between F3Y and DCN (b). The K sv value of DCN was calculated as 37340 M–1, and the LOD was calculated to be 0.14 μM based on 3σ/k (c). In addition, the optical images of F3Y before and after the addition of 176.82 μM DCN in water showed obvious changes, indicating that F3Y may become a portable sensor based on the naked eye (d). The LODs of other DCN detection methods are shown in Table S6. The results show that F3Y has good sensitivity for DCN detection compared with other materials.

elements.content: To test the anti-interference ability of the proposed method, an anti-interference experiment was carried out. The concentration of DCN and other interfering pesticides was 176.82 μM. The fluorescence intensity changes before and after adding interfering pesticides and DCN were recorded. After adding other interfering pesticides, the changes in the fluorescence intensity of F3Y were negligible, but the fluorescence intensity of F3Y was significantly quenched when DCN was added (Figure S27a). As a result, F3Y has good selectivity and anti-interference ability to detect DCN. Figure S27b shows that the detection of the DCN by F3Y can be cycled at least three times.

elements.content: To evaluate the application of F3B in actual samples, we collected water samples from fish ponds and fish tanks at Neijiang Normal University, and no NFAs were detected. The accuracy of the method was verified by adding different concentrations of NFAs standard solution. From Table S7, it was found that the recovery rate of NFAs was in the range of 97.0–105.15%, and the RSD was 0.63–1.45%, which was less than 6.0%. elements.clean_text:
Detection of NFAs and DCN in Real Samples

To evaluate the application of F3B in actual samples, we collected water samples from fish ponds and fish tanks at Neijiang Normal University, and no NFAs were detected. The accuracy of the method was verified by adding different concentrations of NFAs standard solution. From Table S7, it was found that the recovery rate of NFAs was in the range of 97.0-105.15%, and the RSD was 0.63-1.45%, which was less than 6.0%. The above results suggest that the sensor system has the potential to detect NFAs in the environment.

elements.content: To evaluate the application of F3Y in real samples, we collected soil from mountain top orchards for analysis. The collected soil was treated as follows: 20 g of fresh soil was packed in a tray and dried in an oven at 50 °C overnight. After grinding into powder, it was put into a round bottom flask containing 20 mL of N-hexane, put into an ultrasonic water bath for 1 h, and filtered through filter paper. After the filtrate was concentrated, the filtrate was diluted to 5 mL with ultrapure water. The presence of DCN was not found in the soil, and the recovery was calculated by the standard addition method. As shown in Table S8, the recovery of DCN determined by this method was 102.2–106.48%, and the RSD was 0.29–1.69%. Hence, F3Y can be used as a method for DCN detection in the environment.
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the application of F3Y in real samples, we collected soil from mountain top orchards for analysis. The collected soil was treated as follows: 20 g of fresh soil was packed in a tray and dried in an oven at 50 °C overnight. After grinding into powder, it was put into a round bottom flask containing 20 mL of N-hexane, put into an ultrasonic water bath for 1 h, and filtered through filter paper. After the filtrate was concentrated, the filtrate was diluted to 5 mL with ultrapure water. The presence of DCN was not found in the soil, and the recovery was calculated by the standard addition method. As shown in Table S8, the recovery of DCN determined by this method was 102.2-106.48%, and the RSD was 0.29-1.69%. Hence, F3Y can be used as a method for DCN detection in the environment.

elements.content: Considering that lead ions are toxic, to verify whether F3B and F3Y cause secondary contamination after detecting the target analytes, the lead ion concentration in the filtrate was measured by inductively coupled plasma–mass spectrometry (ICP–MS). The results showed that the concentrations of lead ions in F3B and F3Y filtrates were 4 ng/mL and 6 ng/mL, respectively, which were lower than the standards recommended by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and World Health Organization (WHO).

elements.content: In addition, to make the detection method more intuitive and portable, we prepared F3B and F3Y fluorescent test strips with a size of 2.0 × 0.5 cm. The test paper was immersed in antibiotics and pesticides, and the optical image changes were observed under UV light irradiation (365 nm). Figure S28a shows that after submersion in NFZ, NFT, and NFAs, the optical images of the test strip changed from blue to dark; Figure S28b shows that the optical images of the test strip changed from yellow–green to dark after soaking in DCN. As a convenient and portable test strip, the above results show that the materials can realize visual detection of NFZ, NFT, NFAs, and DCN.

elements.clean_text:
Mechanism for Sensing NFAs and DCN

In this study, a possible mechanism of fluorescence quenching was deduced by experiments. First, the PXRD patterns of F3B and F3Y were collected after five cycles of detection of NFAs and DCN, respectively. F3B and F3Y maintained good crystallinity after five cycles, indicating that fluorescence quenching was not caused by frame collapse (Figures S22 and S29). Second, Tables S9 and S10 demonstrate that the size of the simulated antibiotic and pesticide molecules was greater than the size of the F3 pores (6.75 × 6.75 Å). Hence, the possibility of fluorescence quenching caused by guest molecules entering the crystal pores was excluded. Third, combined with c, S18c and S19c, the S-V curve shifts upward at high concentrations and conforms to a first-order exponential equation, indicating that there exist energy transfer processes. As shown in Figure S30a and Table S11, the fluorescence lifetime had almost no change after adding different concentrations of NFAs to F3B, indicating that there were no strong interactions between the antibiotics and F3B. Hence, we speculate that there may be an energy transfer process.

elements.content: The fluorescence lifetime of F3Y decreased significantly after adding different concentrations of DCN (Figure S30b and Table S12), which is a typical dynamic quenching feature. The conclusion of dynamic quenching seems to be contradictory because the S–V plot is linear. Therefore, we carefully analyzed the fluorescence decay profiles after adding DCN and used the two exponential decay components to adequately fit the data. The decrease in the average fluorescence decay lifetime does not come from the shortening of the lifetime of each component but from the increase in the proportion of the fastest relaxation component (τ1) and the decrease in the proportion of the slowest relaxation component (τ2). The proportions of τ1 and τ2 in F3Y were 40.48 and 59.52%, respectively. When 40 μL of DCN was added, the proportion of τ1 increased to 70.13%, while the proportion of τ2 decreased to 29.87%. The collision between DCN and F3Y destroys the excited state, resulting in a decrease in the average fluorescence lifetime of F3Y. Therefore, the quenching process of F3Y induced by DCN was dynamic quenching.

elements.content: For antibiotics and pesticides, the photoinduced electron transfer (PET) process is a recognized quenching mechanism that involves the transfer of electrons from the conduction band (CB) of MOFs to the LUMO (the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals) of the analytes. MOFs are large “molecules” whose valence band and CB energy levels can be similar to molecular orbital energy levels (MO). If the CB energy level of MOFs is higher than the LUMO energy level of the analyte, this will result in the transfer of electrons from the ligand to the analyte, resulting in fluorescence quenching. Therefore, the lower the LUMO energy of the analyte is, the more efficient the fluorescence quenching. As shown in a and Table S13, the LUMO orbitals of DTZ, MDZ, ODZ, TDZ, NFZ, and NFT are lower than the CB levels of ligands so that they can quench the fluorescence of F3B. The LUMO energy levels of NFZ and NFT are the lowest, and the quenching rate is the highest.

elements.content: Another possible mechanism is the competitive energy absorption mechanism. The light absorption efficiency of the MOFs will be reduced when the UV–vis absorption spectrum of the target overlaps with the excitation spectrum of the MOFs, resulting in fluorescence quenching of the MOFs. As depicted in b, the UV–vis absorption spectra of the analytes (NFZ, NFT, and NFAs) overlap significantly with the excitation bands of F3B. Therefore, NFA-induced fluorescence quenching may be ascribed to the collaborative effect of PET and competitive energy absorption.

elements.content: For the pesticide DCN, it can be seen from c and Table S14 that the LUMO energy level of the ligand is higher than that of DCN and CML, but the previous experiments proved that CML has no quenching effect on F3Y. d shows that the UV–vis absorption spectrum of DCN significantly overlaps with the excitation bands of F3Y, while the excitation and fluorescence bands of CML and F3Y do not overlap. In addition, 40 μL of different antibiotics was added to the F3Y suspension, and it was found that F3Y could selectively detect NFAs with a quenching rate of 90.92% (Figure S31a). Adding 32 μL of different pesticides into the F3B suspension, F3B could also selectively detect DCN and the quenching rate was 81.20% (Figure S31b). According to the molecular structure analysis (Figures S17 and S25), DTZ, MDZ, ODZ, and TDZ all have nitro groups, which will cause quenching to a certain extent. Nevertheless, the nitro group in DCN is directly connected to the benzene ring through a conjugation effect. The two chlorine atoms and the nitro group have electron-absorbing effects, resulting in the H atom of the amino group being more likely to interact with the deprotonated carboxyl group in the crystal. However, antibiotics and other pesticide molecules do not have nitro and benzene ring conjugation, so they cannot interact with F3B/F3Y by hydrogen bonds. Hence, the hydrogen bonding interactions between F3Y and DCN should also contribute to the good sensitivity of the detection. Consequently, DCN-induced fluorescence quenching may be mainly attributed to the synergistic effect of PET, competitive energy absorption, and hydrogen bonding interactions.

elements.content: In conclusion, a novel two-dimensional anionic Pb-MOF (F3) with an interlocking structure was successfully synthesized. Due to its interlocking structure, F3 exhibits excellent thermal stability, solvent stability, and a wide range of acid/alkali resistance (pH = 2–12). F3B can be used as a sensitive fluorescent probe to detect NFAs in water, and the detection limit can reach 0.26 μM. F3Y can be used as a chemical sensor to detect DCN in water with an LOD of 0.14 μM. Notably, F3B demonstrated excellent selectivity in the presence of other antibiotics and excellent anti-interference properties against commonly used antibiotics in water. F3Y demonstrated excellent selectivity in the presence of other pesticides and remarkable anti-interference performance against commonly used pesticides in water. Mechanistic studies show that the main reason for the quenching of F3B by antibiotics is the synergistic effect of PET and energy competitive absorption. The main reason for the quenching of F3Y by pesticides is the synergistic effect of PET, energy competitive absorption, and hydrogen bonding interactions. In addition, F3B and F3Y can be made into fluorescent test papers for the visual detection of NFAs and DCN, respectively.

Conclusions

In conclusion, a novel two-dimensional anionic Pb-MOF (F3) with an interlocking structure was successfully synthesized. Due to its interlocking structure, F3 exhibits excellent thermal stability, solvent stability, and a wide range of acid/alkali resistance (pH = 2-12). F3B can be used as a sensitive fluorescent probe to detect NFAs in water, and the detection limit can reach 0.26 μM. F3Y can be used as a chemical sensor to detect DCN in water with an LOD of 0.14 μM. Notably, F3B demonstrated excellent selectivity in the presence of other antibiotics and excellent anti-interference properties against commonly used antibiotics in water. F3Y demonstrated excellent selectivity in the presence of other pesticides and remarkable anti-interference performance against commonly used pesticides in water. Mechanistic studies show that the main reason for the quenching of F3B by antibiotics is the synergistic effect of PET and energy competitive absorption. The main reason for the quenching of F3Y by pesticides is the synergistic effect of PET, energy competitive absorption, and hydrogen bonding interactions. In addition, F3B and F3Y can be made into fluorescent test papers for the visual detection of NFAs and DCN, respectively.

Synthesis of {[(CH3)2NH2]2[Pb(TCBPE)(H2O)2]} n  (F3)

H4TCBPE (8 mg, 0.009 mM) and Pb(NO3)2 (5.96 mg, 0.018 mM) were mixed with DMF (1.5 mL), ACN (0.5 mL), and water (0.5 mL), and 100 μL of 6 M HCl was added to adjust the pH value. The mixture was sonicated for 30 min and then sealed into a 10 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 120 °C for three days and cooled slowly to 25 °C. Pale yellow square crystals were collected and washed with DMF, ACN, and water and then dried naturally. The yield was approximately 44.88% [based on Pb(NO3)2]. cln_elements.content:
The misuse of organic pollutants such as nitrofuran antibiotics (NFAs) and 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline (DCN) has become a hot topic of global concern, and developing rapid, efficient, and accurate techniques for detecting NFAs and pesticides in water is a major challenge. Here, we designed a novel lead-based anion 2D metal–organic framework (MOF)­{[(CH3)2NH2]2[Pb­(TCBPE)­(H2O)2]} n (F3) with interlocking structures, in which TCBPE stands for 1,1,2,2-tetra­(4-carboxylbiphenyl)­ethylene. Powder X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis revealed that F3 has excellent chemical and solvent stability. It is worth noting that F3 has a grinding discoloration effect. The solvent-protected grinding approach achieved F3B with a high quantum yield (QY = 73.77%) and blue fluorescence, while the direct grinding method produced F3Y with a high quantum yield (QY = 37.27%) and yellow–green fluorescence. Importantly, F3B can detect NFAs in water rapidly and sensitively while remaining unaffected by other antibiotics. F3Y can identify DCN in water quickly and selectively while remaining unchanged by other pesticides. F3B demonstrated high selectivity and rapid response to NFAs at a limit of detection (LOD) as low as 0.26 μM, while F3Y indicated high selectivity and responded quickly to DCN in water at an LOD as low as 0.14 μM. The method was successfully applied to detect NFAs in actual water samples of the fish tanks and ponds as well as the pesticide DCN in soil samples. The recovery rates were 97.0–105.15% and 102.2–106.48%, and the relative standard deviations were 0.63–1.45% and 0.29–1.69%, respectively. In addition, F3B and F3Y can be made into fluorescent test papers for the visual detection of NFAs and DCN, respectively. Combined with experiments and density functional theory calculations, the mechanism of fluorescence quenching of MOFs by target analytes was also revealed.

In this paper, a novel two-dimensional anionic framework­{[(CH3)2NH2]2[Pb (TCBPE) (H2O)2]} n (F3) with superior fluorescence properties was constructed by using the H4TCBPE ligand and lead nitrate. Due to the vertical interlocking structure of F3, it exhibits excellent solvent and fluorescence stability in water and other organic solvents. As a result, it is suitable for fluorescence analysis. The blue luminescent crystal powder (F3B) (PLQY = 73.77%) was obtained by the solvent protection grinding method, and the yellow–green luminescent crystal powder (F3Y) (PLQY = 37.27%) was attained by direct grinding. Based on the fluorescence response characteristics, a dual-color luminescent Pb-TCBPE sensing platform in water was constructed, realizing the detection of NFAs by F3B and the detection of DCN by F3Y. The linear range of NFAs was 0.86–29.91 μM with a detection limit of 0.26 μM, whereas the linear range of DCN was 0.46–59.64 μM with a detection limit of 0.14 μM. The method was successfully applied to detect NFAs in actual water samples of fish tanks and ponds and the pesticide DCN in soil samples. The recovery rates were 97.0–105.15% and 102.2–106.48%, and the relative standard deviations (RSDs) were 0.63–1.45% and 0.29–1.69%, respectively. Finally, we prepared a portable fluorescent test paper to visualize and rapidly detect NFAs and pesticide DCN. In addition, the quenching mechanism was investigated by experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Notably, this work is the first to propose a variety of solvent-protected strategies for the preparation of TCBPE-MOFs. This is also the first time that Pb-TCBPE has been synthesized and used to detect antibiotics and pesticides in water, which contributes to the development of multifunctional fluorescent MOF sensors.

Structural Characterization of Compound <bold>F3</bold>

Under the optical microscope, F3 was shown as a regularly shaped pale-yellow square (Figure S8a). The surface of F3 was observed by SEM (Figure S8b), suggesting that F3 was smooth and free of impurities, and the surface roughness (Rq) of F3 measured by AFM was only 0.00146 μm (Figure S8c). The above results show that F3 has a good morphology and smooth surface. PXRD was carried out to confirm the phase purity of compound F3. The positions of the prominent diffraction peaks of the PXRD patterns measured in the experiment are consistent with the simulated ones, proving that F3 is a pure phase (Figure S9). Then, after soaking in aqueous solutions with different pH values for 12 h, the prominent diffraction peaks of the PXRD patterns are still consistent with the simulated peaks, indicating that F3 can remain stable in the pH range of 2–12 (Figure S10a). As depicted in Figure S10b, F3 maintained excellent crystallinity, and the PXRD patterns are in agreement with the simulated patterns after soaking in water and different organic solvents for 12 h, indicating that compound F3 has superb solvent stability. The stability of the solvent lays the foundation for fluorescence sensing in the liquid phase.

XPS spectra were used to determine the elemental composition and valence state of F3. As seen from Figure S11a, elements in complex F3 include Pb, C, N, and O. The high-resolution spectrum of Pb 4f shows that the binding energies are 138.88 eV (Pb 4f7/2) and 143.78 eV (Pb 4f5/2), which prove the existence of Pb­(II) ions (Figure S11b). Figure S11c shows that the high-resolution XPS spectrum of C 1s is convolved into two peaks, with binding energies of 284.80 and 288.27 eV corresponding to the C–C bond and the O–CO bond, respectively, which correspond to carboxylic acid ligands. Figure S11d shows the N 1s high-resolution XPS spectrum with one convolution peak at 402.82 eV attributable to C–NH2, further proving the existence of the dimethylamine cation. Figure S11e shows O 1s high-resolution XPS with two convolution peaks at 531.67 and 533.44 eV attributable to the Pb–O bond and the CO bond.

TGA data were collected in the range of 30 to 800 °C at a rate of 20 °C min–1 under a nitrogen atmosphere to investigate F3’s thermal stability. As shown in Figure S13, the weight loss rate of the TGA curve is approximately 3.12% (calculated to be 3.15%) from 30–138 °C, proving the loss of two coordinated water molecules in F3. When the temperature was increased to 430 °C, the mass of F3 decreased sharply, which was attributed to the collapse of the framework. The above result showed that F3 has excellent thermal stability.

Fluorescence Spectroscopy Analysis

CPs of main-group metals such as Pb­(II) have interesting photochemical and photophysical properties, but there have been few studies on their PL compared with transition metals and lanthanide metals. a shows that F3B and F3Y have broad excitation spectra ranging from 300 to 400 nm. As a practical application, the UV lamp can be used for visual detection, so we all use 365 nm as the wavelength for excitation. As shown in b, the maximum emission wavelengths of F3B, F3Y, and the ligand H4TCBPE are 461, 507, and 484 nm, respectively. The luminescence of F3B and F3Y can be attributed to the charge transfer from ligand-to-metal (LMCT) between the delocalized π-bond of the carboxylic group and the p-orbital of the Pb­(II) center. As shown in c, the fluorescence lifetime of F3Y is 2.08 ns, the fluorescence lifetime of F3B is 1.05 ns, and the fluorescence lifetime of the ligand H4TCBPE is 1.89 ns. Interestingly, the order of life span is in line with the trend of luminous centers, which is consistent with a previous report. The Commission International de I’Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity coordinates of H4TCBPE, F3B, and F3Y are (0.1914, 0.3339), (0.1563, 0.1818), and (0.2672, 0.4273), respectively (d). In addition, both crystal suspensions maintained good dispersibility in water under daylight lamps (e). Moreover, under irradiation with UV light, both crystal suspensions exhibited dazzling fluorescence (f). The quantum yield of F3B in water is as high as 73.77%, and the quantum yield of F3Y powder in water is as high as 37.27%.

To prove the application value of F3B in realistic environments, the fluorescence response characteristics of F3B under different pH values were investigated. Figure S15a shows that the fluorescence intensity of F3B did not change much in the pH range from 2 to 12, indicating that the probe could maintain fluorescence stability over a wide pH range. In addition, the effect of different kinds of ions on the fluorescence intensity of F3B was also investigated. As shown in Figure S15b, the effect of these cations and anions on the luminescence intensity is negligible. F3B was immersed in 10 kinds of common organic solvents (Figure S15c) and a pH range from 2 to 12 for 12 h, and PXRD patterns were collected (Figure S15d). The PXRD pattern showed that F3B maintained good crystallinity after soaking. This means that F3B is stable in different solvents and over a wide range of pH values. To explore the sensing ability of F3B to trace antibiotics in aqueous solutions, the stability of F3B in water was analyzed by time-dependent luminescence intensity. As shown in Figure S16, F3B exhibited a characteristic emission peak at 461 nm, which is close to the emission peak of the ligand (485 nm), indicating that the luminescence of F3B is mainly attributed to the emission of the organic ligand. After 5 h of immersion in water, the fluorescence intensity of F3B did not change. Moreover, the fluorescence intensity decreased only slightly after extending the time to 24 h.
