Under the optical microscope, F3 was shown as a regularly shaped pale-yellow square (Figure S8a). The surface of F3 was observed by SEM (Figure S8b), suggesting that F3 was smooth and free of impurities, and the surface roughness (Rq) of F3 measured by AFM was only 0.00146 μm (Figure S8c). The above results show that F3 has a good morphology and smooth surface. PXRD was carried out to confirm the phase purity of compound F3. The positions of the prominent diffraction peaks of the PXRD patterns measured in the experiment are consistent with the simulated ones, proving that F3 is a pure phase (Figure S9). Then, after soaking in aqueous solutions with different pH values for 12 h, the prominent diffraction peaks of the PXRD patterns are still consistent with the simulated peaks, indicating that F3 can remain stable in the pH range of 2-12 (Figure S10a). As depicted in Figure S10b, F3 maintained excellent crystallinity, and the PXRD patterns are in agreement with the simulated patterns after soaking in water and different organic solvents for 12 h, indicating that compound F3 has superb solvent stability. The stability of the solvent lays the foundation for fluorescence sensing in the liquid phase.

XPS spectra were used to determine the elemental composition and valence state of F3. As seen from Figure S11a, elements in complex F3 include Pb, C, N, and O. The high-resolution spectrum of Pb 4f shows that the binding energies are 138.88 eV (Pb 4f7/2) and 143.78 eV (Pb 4f5/2), which prove the existence of Pb(II) ions (Figure S11b). Figure S11c shows that the high-resolution XPS spectrum of C 1s is convolved into two peaks, with binding energies of 284.80 and 288.27 eV corresponding to the C-C bond and the O-CO bond, respectively, which correspond to carboxylic acid ligands. Figure S11d shows the N 1s high-resolution XPS spectrum with one convolution peak at 402.82 eV attributable to C-NH2, further proving the existence of the dimethylamine cation. Figure S11e shows O 1s high-resolution XPS with two convolution peaks at 531.67 and 533.44 eV attributable to the Pb-O bond and the CO bond.

TGA data were collected in the range of 30 to 800 °C at a rate of 20 °C min-1 under a nitrogen atmosphere to investigate F3's thermal stability. As shown in Figure S13, the weight loss rate of the TGA curve is approximately 3.12% (calculated to be 3.15%) from 30-138 °C, proving the loss of two coordinated water molecules in F3. When the temperature was increased to 430 °C, the mass of F3 decreased sharply, which was attributed to the collapse of the framework. The above result showed that F3 has excellent thermal stability.

Fluorescence Spectroscopy Analysis

CPs of main-group metals such as Pb(II) have interesting photochemical and photophysical properties, but there have been few studies on their PL compared with transition metals and lanthanide metals. a shows that F3B and F3Y have broad excitation spectra ranging from 300 to 400 nm. As a practical application, the UV lamp can be used for visual detection, so we all use 365 nm as the wavelength for excitation. As shown in b, the maximum emission wavelengths of F3B, F3Y, and the ligand H4TCBPE are 461, 507, and 484 nm, respectively. The luminescence of F3B and F3Y can be attributed to the charge transfer from ligand-to-metal (LMCT) between the delocalized π-bond of the carboxylic group and the p-orbital of the Pb(II) center. As shown in c, the fluorescence lifetime of F3Y is 2.08 ns, the fluorescence lifetime of F3B is 1.05 ns, and the fluorescence lifetime of the ligand H4TCBPE is 1.89 ns. Interestingly, the order of life span is in line with the trend of luminous centers, which is consistent with a previous report. The Commission International de I'Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity coordinates of H4TCBPE, F3B, and F3Y are (0.1914, 0.3339), (0.1563, 0.1818), and (0.2672, 0.4273), respectively (d). In addition, both crystal suspensions maintained good dispersibility in water under daylight lamps (e). Moreover, under irradiation with UV light, both crystal suspensions exhibited dazzling fluorescence (f). The quantum yield of F3B in water is as high as 73.77%, and the quantum yield of F3Y powder in water is as high as 37.27%.

To prove the application value of F3B in realistic environments, the fluorescence response characteristics of F3B under different pH values were investigated. Figure S15a shows that the fluorescence intensity of F3B did not change much in the pH range from 2 to 12, indicating that the probe could maintain fluorescence stability over a wide pH range. In addition, the effect of different kinds of ions on the fluorescence intensity of F3B was also investigated. As shown in Figure S15b, the effect of these cations and anions on the luminescence intensity is negligible. F3B was immersed in 10 kinds of common organic solvents (Figure S15c) and a pH range from 2 to 12 for 12 h, and PXRD patterns were collected (Figure S15d). The PXRD pattern showed that F3B maintained good crystallinity after soaking. This means that F3B is stable in different solvents and over a wide range of pH values. To explore the sensing ability of F3B to trace antibiotics in aqueous solutions, the stability of F3B in water was analyzed by time-dependent luminescence intensity. As shown in Figure S16, F3B exhibited a characteristic emission peak at 461 nm, which is close to the emission peak of the ligand (485 nm), indicating that the luminescence of F3B is mainly attributed to the emission of the organic ligand. After 5 h of immersion in water, the fluorescence intensity of F3B did not change. Moreover, the fluorescence intensity decreased only slightly after extending the time to 24 h.

cln_elements.content:
To further demonstrate that NFT or NFZ induces fluorescence quenching, we performed a concentration-dependent study of the luminescence properties of F3B in the presence of NFZ or NFT. It can be observed that with the addition of NFZ or NFT, the fluorescence intensity of F3B gradually decreases (Figures S18a and S19a). Furthermore, when the NFZ or NFT concentration was increased to 196.078 μM, the fluorescence intensity was almost completely quenched, and the quenching efficiency of NFZ and NFT was 92.6 and 90.4%, respectively (Figures S18b and S19b). The quenching effect can be quantitatively calculated by the Stern–Volmer expression: I 0/I – 1 = K sv [C] (I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of F3B before and after adding the analyte, respectively); [C] = the analyte concentration; K sv is the quenching constant (M–1). As shown in Figures S18c and S19c, the fluorescence intensity of the I 0/I ratio has a good linear relationship with the NFZ or NFT concentration in the range of 1.15–29.91 μM and 1.09–29.91 μM, respectively. The K sv value is calculated as 1.934 × 104 for NFZ and 2.01 × 104 for NFT, revealing a strong quenching effect on the luminescence emission intensity of F3B. Based on 3σ/k (the RSD of 10 blank measurements is expressed as σ; and k represents the slope of linear fitting between the concentration and the relative luminescence intensity in the linear range), the LODs for NFZ and NFT are estimated to be 0.35 and 0.33 μM, respectively. Moreover, the optical images of F3B in water before and after the addition of 196.078 μM NFZ or NFT had obvious luminescence color changes (Figures S18d and S19d), indicating that F3B has the potential to be a portable sensor based on the naked eye. The fluorescence titration experiments showed that F3B has good application prospects in the detection of NFZ or NFT in water.

In addition, the ability of F3B as a fluorescence probe to detect NFAs was explored by a fluorescence titration experiment. The fluorescence intensity of F3B decreased gradually with increasing concentrations (0–196.078 μM) of NFAs (a). As shown in b,c, in the range of low concentrations (0.86–29.91 μM), the relationship between the concentration of NFAs and the fluorescence intensity of F3B agrees with the S–V equation, showing a good linear relationship. With a further increase in the concentration, the S–V plot deviated from linearity and bent upward, and the linear relationship agrees with the first-order exponential fitting equation, which may be attributed to the existence of static or dynamic quenching processes or energy transfer processes. When the concentration of NFAs reached 196.078 μM, the fluorescence intensity quenching of F3B was visible to the naked eye (d), and the quenching rate was 93.66%. The K sv value of NFAs was 20340 M–1, and the LOD was calculated to be 0.26 μM.

We accidently discovered that F3Y could detect the pesticide of DCN, so we investigated the quenching process of F3Y by DCN. Figure S23a shows that F3Y has good fluorescence stability in the pH range of 5–9. The addition of common ions to the environment has almost no effect on the fluorescence intensity of F3Y (Figure S23b). After immersing F3Y in 10 kinds of common organic solvents and a pH aqueous solution (pH range from 2 to 12) for 12 h, the PXRD patterns were collected. The results showed that the shape of the diffraction peak and position of F3Y were unchanged in the pH range of 5–9 and water (Figure S23d). In the pH range of 2–4, 10–12 and organic solvents (Figure S23c,e,f), F3Y appeared at a new diffraction peak, resulting from the interaction between the crystal and organic solvent, strong acid, and alkali solution. In this work, F3Y is applied in water, so we consider that F3Y has good stability in water and a pH range of 5–9. The fluorescence stability of F3Y in water was analyzed by time-dependent luminescence intensity. F3Y exhibited a characteristic emission peak at 507 nm. In addition, the position and intensity of the fluorescence peak of F3Y in water for 5 h were unchanged, while the fluorescence intensity decreased after extending the time for 24 h. However, the position of the fluorescence peak remained unchanged (Figure S24). The above results showed that F3Y has good fluorescence stability in water.

In addition, the sensitivity of the probe was studied by dripping DCN solution into an F3Y suspension, and the changes in the fluorescence spectra were recorded (a). The fluorescence intensity of F3Y decreased with increasing DCN concentration, and the fluorescence quenching rate reached 79.59% when the concentration reached 176.82 μM. In the low concentration range of 0.46–59.64 μM, the concentration of DCN and the fluorescence intensity of F3Y complied with the Stern–Volmer equation, showing a good linear relationship (R 2 = 0.999). With increasing DCN concentration, the S–V equation gradually shifts and bends downward, which may be attributed to the static or dynamic quenching relationship or energy transfer processes between F3Y and DCN (b). The K sv value of DCN was calculated as 37340 M–1, and the LOD was calculated to be 0.14 μM based on 3σ/k (c). In addition, the optical images of F3Y before and after the addition of 176.82 μM DCN in water showed obvious changes, indicating that F3Y may become a portable sensor based on the naked eye (d). The LODs of other DCN detection methods are shown in Table S6. The results show that F3Y has good sensitivity for DCN detection compared with other materials.

Considering that lead ions are toxic, to verify whether F3B and F3Y cause secondary contamination after detecting the target analytes, the lead ion concentration in the filtrate was measured by inductively coupled plasma–mass spectrometry (ICP–MS). The results showed that the concentrations of lead ions in F3B and F3Y filtrates were 4 ng/mL and 6 ng/mL, respectively, which were lower than the standards recommended by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and World Health Organization (WHO).

metadata.title:
Dual-Color
2D Lead–Organic Framework with Two-Fold
Interlocking Structures for the Detection of Nitrofuran Antibiotics
and 2,6-Dichloro-4-nitroaniline
